{{Refimprove|date=September 2009}}
'''Enterprise forms automation''' is a company-wide computer system or set of systems for managing, distributing, [[Document processing|completing and processing]] paper-based forms, applications, surveys, contracts and other documents. It plays a vital role towards achieving the goal of a [[paperless office]].
The term "enterprise forms automation" was first used in the mid 1990s by [[JetForm]] Corporation to describe their solution to automating paperwork. This process was later acquired by [[Adobe Systems]] and is now part of the [[Adobe LiveCycle]] suite of products. In 2004 Efficient Technology Inc became the first company to apply this term in the [[software as a service]].
This term is intended to refer to the automation of paper-based processes that specifically rely on documents (forms, applications, etc.) that retain their paper-based look and feel even if not printed out during the process. In order for a forms automation solution to be considered an ‘Enterprise Forms Automation’ solution it must meet the requirements of [[enterprise software]] and be specifically focused on automating paperwork and paper-based forms.
==Impact== Organizations implement enterprise software solutions in order to automate major functions and large processes as these areas offer the greatest cost savings and return on investment compared to smaller projects. Enterprise-level implementations often cost well over $100,000 and therefore take many months to realize cost savings. As such, automating smaller functions are ignored due to the lack of immediate financial benefit or cost savings. As functions become more and more automated while software costs for enterprise systems drop in price, organizations begin automating lower-level functions in order to reap additional cost savings and become more efficient. In addition, through the advent of standards like Adobe’s PDF model and service models like Quik!, automating the process of filling out forms is one such area that companies seek to automate via Enterprise Forms Automation solutions.
Automating forms also has a positive ‘green’ impact on the environment. In order to reduce waste and carbon emissions, companies seek ways to eliminate paper. By deploying an Enterprise Forms Automation system, companies can eliminate paper entirely or significantly reduce how much paper is used, while greatly reducing shipping and handling costs, storage costs, and printing costs associated to pre-printed forms. In addition, automating paper-based processes greatly speeds up the time it takes to perform transactions, which results in fewer errors, rejections and revisions and has the benefit of freeing up the time spent by users on manual labor.
== Implementation == === DMS === In today’s implementation of the paperless office concept there are two main focuses: creating documents and managing documents. Since major systems have already displaced paper altogether (e.g. [[enterprise resource planning]], [[customer relationship management]], [[accounting software]], etc.), the paper that continues to be in use is largely generated by processes that capture data, generate reports and distribute communications. As software and computers have evolved, the first problem to be addressed has been the management of existing and legacy documents through [[document management system]]s.
Document management and archiving systems do offer some methods of automating forms. Typically, the point in which document management systems start working with a document is when the document is scanned and/or sent into the system. Many document management systems include the ability to read documents via [[optical character recognition]] (OCR) and use that data within the document management system’s framework. While this technology is essential to achieving a paperless office<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.quikforms.com/WHITEPAPERAchievingThePaperlessOffice.pdf |title=Achieving The Paperless Office |last=Walker |first=Richard |authorlink=Richard D. Walker |journal=Efficient Technology Inc |date=2009-08-07 }}</ref> it does not address the processes that generate paper in the first place.
The ultimate step towards eliminating paper is to change the way that documents are created. In 1993 Adobe Systems introduced the [[Portable Document Format]] (PDF) in order to facilitate the exchange of documents in a universal manner across most computer platforms. This format has laid the foundation for creating, transporting, working on and archiving electronic documents and in 2008 became an ISO standard.<ref>{{cite web | title = ISO 32000-1:2008 | publisher = International Organization For Standardization | date = July 1, 2008 | url = http://www.iso.org/iso/catalogue_detail?csnumber=51502}}</ref> In addition, the PDF model established a method for automating forms that allows forms to be prefilled with existing data and manually entered on a PC screen which can greatly reduce and/or eliminate the number of paper forms being printed.
=== Implementation tools === A typical Enterprise Forms Automation implementation typically combines the following technologies: * Library of electronic versions of paper-based documents (PDF format or other comparable format) * Data store of existing data and/or web page to collect data to fill onto forms * Software to pre-fill existing data from databases and data stores onto electronic forms * Software to save forms that are in process and/or partially completed * Software to capture and translate electronic form data * Workflow systems to manage the interaction with forms and data * Two-way messaging between forms and systems during submission and validation * Barcode software to match images of forms with electronic form data * Digital signature solutions to capture signatures electronically
=== Implementation challenges === The primary challenge to making use of these technologies is a matter of resource planning and implementation costs, however all of the necessary technologies have been in existence since at least 2000. Furthermore, the [[Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act]] (ESIGN Act) was signed into legislation by Congress requiring that digital signatures be accepted as valid signatures. But even with the law in effect, companies have been slow to adopt such solutions due to the cost and skills required to design, build and maintain such systems at a reasonable price.
A secondary challenge is integrating the electronic forms into an existing process, whereby existing data stores can be accessed and supplied to and from the forms. While tools to assist with the integration exist, most implementations require custom programming efforts to the specific forms and data sources.
Many of these challenges are being addressed by middleware solutions, technology platforms and services that tie all the pieces together. Known as [[Enterprise Application Integration]] (“EAI”), developers of EAI solutions are continually introducing new cost-effective methods to take advantage of web-based and centrally-managed capabilities plus the ability to leverage legacy system architecture.<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Ruh | first1 = William A. | last2 = Maginnis | first2 = Francis X. | last3 = Brown | first3 = William | title = Enterprise application integration: a Wiley tech brief | publisher = John Wiley & Sons, Inc | year = 2001 | pages = 1–11 | isbn = 0-471-37641-8}}</ref> With each advancement in EAI technologies enterprise forms automation becomes easier to implement and manage.
== See also == *[[Document automation]] *[[Form (document)]] *[[Intelligent document]]
== References == {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Enterprise Forms Automation}}

revision.text:
'''Enterprise social software''' (also known as or regarded as a major component of [[Enterprise 2.0]]), comprises [[social software]] as used in "[[Business|enterprise]]" (business/[[commerce|commercial]]) contexts. It includes social and networked modifications to corporate [[intranet]]s and other classic [[software]] platforms used by large companies to organize their [[communication]]. In contrast to traditional [[enterprise software]], which imposes structure prior to use, enterprise social software tends to encourage use prior to providing structure.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Makkonen | first1 = H. | last2 = Virtanen | first2 = K. | year = 2015 | title = Social capital approach on Enterprise 2.0: a multiple case study | doi = 10.1080/09537325.2015.1061120 | journal = Technology Analysis & Strategic Management| volume = 27| issue = | pages = 1212–1225}}</ref>
Carl Frappaolo and Dan Keldsen defined Enterprise 2.0 in a report written for [[Association for Information and Image Management]] (AIIM) as "a [[system]] of [[World Wide Web|web]]-based [[technology|technologies]] that provide rapid and agile collaboration, information sharing, emergence and integration capabilities in the extended enterprise".<ref> {{cite web|url=http://www.aiim.org/What-is-Web-2.0.aspx|title=What is Web 2.0?|accessdate=2009-01-20|author=Carl Frappaolo and Dan Keldsen|last=|first=|authorlink=|coauthors=|date=|year=2008|month=|work=|publisher=Association for Information and Image Management|location=|pages=|doi=|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090131142014/http://www.aiim.org/What-is-Web-2.0.aspx|archivedate=2009-01-31|quote=AIIM defines Enterprise 2.0 as a system of web-based technologies that provide rapid and agile collaboration, information sharing, emergence and integration capabilities in the extended enterprise.|deadurl=yes|df=}} </ref>
== Applications ==
=== Functionality ===
Social software for an enterprise must (according to [[Andrew McAfee]], Associate Professor, [[Harvard Business School]]) have the following functionality to work well {{Harv|McAfee|2006}}:<ref name=":0">McAfee, Andrew, P. "Enterprise 2.0: The Dawn of Emergent Collaboration" (MIT Sloan Management Review), Spring 2006, Vol.47, No.3</ref>
* Search: allowing users to search for other users or content * Links: grouping similar users or content together * Authoring: including blogs and wikis * Tags: allowing users to [[tag (metadata)|tag]] content * Extensions: recommendations of users; or content based on profile * Signals: allowing people to subscribe to users or content with RSS feeds
McAfee recommends installing easy-to-use software which does not impose any rigid structure on users. He envisages an informal [[roll-out]], but on a common platform to enable future collaboration between areas. He also recommends strong and visible [[management|managerial]] support to achieve this.<ref name=":0" />
In 2007 [[Dion Hinchcliffe]] expanded the list above by adding the following four functions:<ref>*Hinchcliffe, Dion. [http://www.zdnet.com/blog/hinchcliffe/the-state-of-enterprise-2-0/143 "The state of Enterprise 2.0"], ''ZDNET.com'', London, October 22, 2007.</ref>
# Freeform function: no barriers to authorship (meaning free from a learning curve or from restrictions) # Network-oriented function, requiring web-addressable content in all cases # Social function: stressing transparency (to access), diversity (in content and community members) and openness (to structure) # Emergence function: requiring the provision of approaches that detect and leverage the collective wisdom of the community
[[Enterprise search]] differs from a typical web search in its focus on "use within an organization by employees seeking information held internally, in a variety of formats and locations, including databases, [[document management system]]s, and other [[wikt:repository|repositories]]".<ref>"Enterprise Search: Seek and Ye Might Find", ''Computers in Libraries'', July/August 2008, p. 22.</ref>
=== Criticism ===
There has been recent criticism that the adaptation of the social paradigm (e.g. openness and altruistic behavior) does not always work well for the enterprise setting, which led some authors to question the proper functioning of enterprise social software.<ref>Wang Y, Greaseley A, Thanassoulis E (2011). Combining ERP Systems with Enterprise 2.0, in P. Powell and R. Martinho (eds.) Enterprise Information Systems, Heidelberg: Springer, pp. 198–207</ref> The findings from a novel study suggests that free and non-anonymous sharing of trusted information (beyond marketing or product information) is significantly influenced by concerns from business users.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Mettler T, Winter R |title=Are business users social? A design experiment exploring information sharing in enterprise social systems |journal=Journal of Information Technology |year=2016 |doi=10.1057/jit.2015.28 |volume=31 |pages=101–114}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Business Intelligence 2.0]] (BI 2.0) * [[Collaborative software]] * [[Enterprise bookmarking]] * [[Semantic Web]] * [[Semantic wiki]] * [[SLATES]] * [[Wikinomics]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Enterprise Social Software}} [[Category:Business terms]] [[Category:Social networking services]] [[Category:Social information processing]]

{{Infobox organization | name = Estonian Chamber of Commerce and Industry | logo = | type = | founded_date = 1925 | founder = | location = [[Estonia]], [[Tallinn]] | origins = | key_people = Toomas Luman, President | area_served = Estonia | focus = | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = | homepage = [http://www.koda.ee/ www.koda.ee] (Estonian, English, Russian) | tax_exempt = | dissolved = | footnotes = }} [[File:Eesti Kaubandus-Tööstuskoda.JPG|thumb|Estonian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Tallinn, Toom-Kooli 17]] '''The Estonian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (ECCI)''' is a [[business network]] in [[Estonia]].<ref>International Chamber of Commerce web-site listing of member organizations http://www.iccwbo.org/Products-and-Services/Trade-facilitation/ATA-connections/ATA-Estonia/</ref><ref>Estonian Government Web-Site "Gateway to Estonia" https://www.eesti.ee/eng/contacts/eesti_kaubandus_toostuskoda</ref><ref>Estonoian Tourist Board http://www.visitestonia.com/en/estonian-chamber-of-commerce-and-industry</ref> The largest in the country, it has over 3000 members.<ref>ECCI web-site http://www.koda.ee/en</ref> The chamber has operated continuously since 1989. Originally established in 1925,<ref>ECCI web-site http://www.koda.ee/en</ref> it was closed down after 15 years during the Soviet occupation, resuming after re-independence in 1989.
==Organization== The ECCI is governed<ref>ECCI web-site http://www.koda.ee/en/chamber-of-commerce/structure-and-staff/</ref> by a board of 15 people, with a President. Staff are employed at the main office in [[Tallinn]], and also in regional offices in [[Pärnu]] (west coast), [[Tartu]] (south-east/central), [[Jõhvi]] (east) and [[Kuressaare]] (western isles).
== Services of the Estonian Chamber of Commerce and Industry == The services offered by the Chamber include consultations, issue of foreign trade documents, searching for cooperation partners, contact events, training and other activities necessary for business activities of entrepreneurs. In providing services the Chamber is supported by competent personnel and diverse databases that contain information regarding companies, laws and regulations etc. The Chamber of Commerce pays a lot of attention to communication between the members and facilitating business activities.
==Publications== Publications<ref>ECCI web-site http://www.koda.ee/index.php?id=11522</ref> include: Leading Brands of Estonia <ref>News article on the City of Tallinn web-site http://www.tallinn.ee/eng/ksf-eng/The-Estonian-Chamber-of-Commerce-and-Industry-has-produced-a-book-entitled-Leading-Brands-of-Estonia</ref> and Estonian Export Directory.<ref>Estonian Export Directory web-site http://www.estonianexport.ee/</ref> The ECCI was involved in the creation of the national standards body for Estonia, known as Eesti Standardikeskus (EVS), as a non-profit association. EVS is recognised by the [[International Organization for Standardization]].<ref>ISO web-site http://www.iso.org/iso/home/about/iso_members/iso_member_body.htm?member_id=1721</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Other uses|Dave Boswell (disambiguation){{!}}David Boswell (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox person | name = Franklin David Boswell | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = <!-- {{Birth year and age|YYYY}} --> | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = [[Canada]] | other_names = | known_for = Awarded the [[J.W. Graham Medal]] in 2003 | occupation = [[Computer Scientist]], software executive }} '''Dave Boswell''' (born c. 1956) is a [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[computer scientist]] who was awarded the [[J.W. Graham Medal]] for his contributions to the field in 2003.<ref name=JWGraham-1> {{cite news| url =https://math.uwaterloo.ca/math/alumni-friends/alumni-awards/jw-graham-medal-award/gallery-past-recipients/f-david-boswell| title =F. David Boswell: 2003 recipient of the J.W. Graham Medal| publisher =[[Faculty of Mathematics, University of Waterloo]]| author =| date =| page =| location =| isbn =|trans-title=| archivedate =2012-12-17| archiveurl =https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=https%3A%2F%2Fmath.uwaterloo.ca%2Fmath%2Falumni-friends%2Falumni-awards%2Fjw-graham-medal-award%2Fgallery-past-recipients%2Ff-david-boswell&date=2012-12-17| deadurl =yes| quote =David held executive management positions with software companies ranging across the spectrum of growth stages, including LivePage Corporation, Sybase Inc., Powersoft Corporation and Watcom.| df =}} </ref><ref name=JWGraham-2> {{cite news |url = http://www.adm.uwaterloo.ca/infonews/release/2003/108%20Graham%20Medal%20for%20David%20Boswell,%20June%202,%202003.html |title = Leading IT executive wins 2003 J. W. Graham Medal |publisher = [[University of Waterloo]] |year = 2003 |accessdate = 2012-12-17 |archivedate = 2012-12-17 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.adm.uwaterloo.ca%2Finfonews%2Frelease%2F2003%2F108%2520Graham%2520Medal%2520for%2520David%2520Boswell%2C%2520June%25202%2C%25202003.html&date=2012-12-17 |deadurl = yes |quote = After graduation, Boswell stayed on campus developing compilers and operating systems at the UW's Computer Systems Group and teaching in the computer science department (now the School of Computer Science). In 1988, Dave joined the management team of UW spin-off WATCOM Systems, which became recognized as an industry leader in PC development tools and database systems. |df = }} </ref>
== Biography == Boswell earned his undergraduate and Masters in Computer Science at the [[University of Waterloo]] in [[Ontario]], Canada. While he was a student and after he earned his masters in 1980, Boswell worked under [[J. Wesley Graham]], a senior Computer Scientist at the University of Waterloo, who had broadly managed teams at Waterloo that developed several widely used [[compiler|computer language compilers]].
One of the first languages that was his design was the ″[[Waterloo Systems Language]]″, intended for systems programming, which introduced some new [[control flow|flow control constructs]].<ref> {{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=C1dOXwAACAAJ&dq=%E2%80%B3Waterloo+Systems+Language%E2%80%B3&hl=en&sa=X&ei=XObPUMuiBeaayQHt8IGICw&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAQ | title = Waterloo Systems Language | publisher = [[Watfac Pubs]] | author = F.D. Boswell | year = 1982 | isbn = 9780919884007 | accessdate = 2012-12-17 | quote = }} </ref>
Boswell worked in compiler design at the University of Waterloo's Computer Systems Group until 1988, when he was one of the founders of [[Watcom]].<ref name=JWGraham-1/><ref name=JWGraham-2/> Watcom's other products were written in the Waterloo Systems Language.<ref> {{cite news | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=w1aA2lOwdNIC&pg=PA208&dq=%E2%80%B3Waterloo+Systems+Language%E2%80%B3&hl=en&sa=X&ei=XObPUMuiBeaayQHt8IGICw&ved=0CDwQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%E2%80%B3Waterloo%20Systems%20Language%E2%80%B3&f=false | title = Watcom Markets University Expertise | publisher = [[PC Magazine]] | author = John Helliwell | date = 1985-04-02 | page = 208 | location = | isbn = | accessdate = 2012-12-17 | quote = }} </ref> Watcom developed [[Watcom C]] and several other successful products until it was acquired by [[Powersoft]] in 1994 for $100 million.<ref name=NYTimes1994-04-13> {{cite news |url = https://www.nytimes.com/1994/04/13/business/business-technology-the-canadian-triangle-where-high-tech-reigns.html |title = BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY; The Canadian Triangle Where High Tech Reigns |publisher = [[New York Times]] |author = Clyde H. Farnsworth |date = 1994-04-13 |page = |location = |isbn = |accessdate = 2012-12-17 |trans-title=|archivedate = 2012-12-17 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F1994%2F04%2F13%2Fbusiness%2Fbusiness-technology-the-canadian-triangle-where-high-tech-reigns.html&date=2012-12-17 |deadurl = yes |quote = As head of the university's Computer Systems Group, Professor Graham founded the Watcom International Corporation to produce software he developed that makes it easier to learn computer programming. The software has been used by more than one million students worldwide. |df = }} </ref><ref name=ITBusiness2007-04-09> {{cite news |url = http://www.itbusiness.ca/it/client/en/home/News.asp?id=42952 |title = U of Waterloo alumni look back on creator of Fortran variant: Wes Graham was critical to the development of popular WATFOR |publisher = [[IT Business]] |author = Shane Schick |date = 2007-04-09 |page = |location = |isbn = |accessdate = 2012-12-17 |trans-title=|archivedate = 2012-12-17 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.itbusiness.ca%2Fit%2Fclient%2Fen%2Fhome%2FNews.asp%3Fid%3D42952&date=2012-12-17 |deadurl = yes |quote = This year the University of Waterloo will be celebrating the 40th anniversary of its computer science department. A key figure from those early days was J. Wesley Graham, a professor who led a team of students to create the Waterloo Fortran IV compiler, also known as WATFOR. Initially developed for the IBM 7040 computer in the summer of 1965, WATFOR later ran on the IBM 360/370, DEC PDP-11 and VAX machines, received rave reviews internationally and led to a spin-off company, WATCOM. Graham died in 1999. |df = }} </ref> Powersoft was in turn acquired by [[Sybase]] and Boswell was made a Sybase vice-president.<ref name=JWGraham-1/><ref> {{cite news | url = https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/access/498185971.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Apr+12%2C+1997&author=Mike+Strathdee&pub=Waterloo+Region+Record&desc=Sybase+has+%27jewel%27+in+Waterloo%3A+World%27s+seventh+largest+computer+firm+looks+to+division+to+turn+around+its+fortunes&pqatl=google | title = Sybase has 'jewel' in Waterloo: World's seventh largest computer firm looks to division to turn around its fortunes | publisher = [[Kitchener Waterloo Record]] | author = Mike Strathdee | date = 1997-04-12 | page = E.1 | accessdate = 2012-12-17 | quote = Waterloo has also proved to be a great training ground for Sybase executives. Three former Watcom executives -- David Boswell, Craig Dynes and David Yach -- now hold senior management positions with Sybase in the U.S.. }} </ref>
In 1998 Boswell left Sybase and was one of the founders of [[LivePage]], in Waterloo.<ref> {{cite news | url = https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/access/434672691.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Sep+21%2C+1999&author=Mike+Strathdee&pub=Waterloo+Region+Record&desc=LivePage+sold+for+%2419M%3B+Toronto%27s+Janna+Systems+buys+Waterloo+software+firm+for+cash%2C+shares&pqatl=google | title = LivePage sold for $19M; Toronto's Janna Systems buys Waterloo software firm for cash, shares | publisher = [[Kitchener Waterloo Record]] | author = Mike Strathdee | date = 1999-09-21 | page = C.02 | accessdate = 2012-12-17 | quote = LivePage president David Boswell will become executive vice- president of marketing for Janna, based out of the Bay area of California. Boswell described the two companies as being "a natural fit." }} </ref> In 1999 Boswell was the President of LivePage when it merged or was acquired by [[Janna Systems]], for $19 million.
==References== {{reflist|2}}
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20121019234055/http://math.uwaterloo.ca/math/alumni-friends/alumni-awards/jw-graham-medal-award/gallery-past-recipients/f-david-boswell F. David Boswell] 2003 recipient of the J.W. Graham Medal at uwaterloo.ca
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Boswell, F. David}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Canadian businesspeople]] [[Category:Canadian computer scientists]] [[Category:University of Waterloo alumni]] [[Category:J.W. Graham Medal awardees]]

{{Infobox organization |image = Federation of Small Businesses Logo.png |caption = The New FSB Logo as of 2016 |motto = Experts in Business |formation = 1974 |status = [[Non-profit organization|Not for profit company]] |purpose = Membership body for small businesses and the self-employed |headquarters = [[Blackpool]], England |leader_title = National Chairman |leader_name = Mike Cherry |leader_title2 = National Vice Chairman |leader_name2 = Melanie Ulyatt |leader_name3 = Dave Stallon |leader_title3 = Commercial Director |leader_title4 = Finance Director |leader_name4 = David Miles |board_of_directors = Mike Cherry, Peter Davys, Alexis Lay, Gary Lovatt, Gillian MacEwan, Martin McTague, David Miles, Ian O'Donnell, Dave Stallon, Melanie Ulyatt, Veronika Weisweiller |main_organ = Board of Directors |subsidiaries = FSB Publications Limited, FSB Recruitment Limited, FSB Sales Limited, F.S.B. (Member Services) Limited, FSB Gold Club Limited, Keep Trade Local Ltd, Real Life Entrepreneurs Limited |volunteers = <!-- Numbers and/or types of volunteers --> |formerly = [[National Federation of Self Employed]] |name = Federation of Small Businesses |size = 230 |native_name = National Federation of Self Employed & Small Businesses |abbreviation = FSB |registration_id = 1263540 |location = [[UK]] |membership = >160,000 |membership_year = 2016 |revenue = £25.6M |revenue_year = 2016 |website = {{official|http://www.fsb.org.uk }} |staff = 211 |staff_year = 2016 |volunteers_year = <!-- Year to which volunteer numbers/data apply --> }} The '''Federation of Small Businesses''' ('''FSB''') is a UK business organisation representing [[Small and medium-sized enterprises|small and medium-sized businesses]]. It was formed in 1974 as the National Federation of Self Employed (NFSE).<ref>{{cite web|title= History|url=https://candidates.fsb.org.uk/our-history.asp|publisher=Federation of Small Businesses}}</ref> The current name for the organisation was adopted in 1991. It is registered with Companies House as The National Federation of Self Employed & Small Businesses Limited (company number 1263540).<ref>{{Cite book|title=FSB Annual Report 1991|year=1991|publisher=FSB|}}</ref>
FSB is a member-led, not-for-profit and non-party political organisation.<ref>{{cite web|title=About the FSB|url=http://www.fsb.org.uk/about-us|website=Federation of Small Businesses}}</ref> FSB is a lobbying organisation representing small firms and the self-employed to UK, national, local and devolved government.<ref>{{cite web|title=FSB Lobbying|url=http://www.fsb.org.uk/benefits/support/lobbying|website=Federation of Small Businesses}}</ref> FSB offers its members a range of benefits, such as a 24-hour legal advice line and free business banking.<ref>{{cite web|title=FSB Member Benefits|url=http://www.fsb.org.uk/benefits|website=Federation of Small Businesses}}</ref>
In January 2018, FSB's Board of Directors altered the organisation's volunteer structure by switching from elected Branches & Regions to an unelected, ad-hoc approach to local lobbying & representation. This necessitated changes to FSB's National Council which now comprises 12 appointed representatives, selected from the 9 English regions and the 3 devolved countries.
In 2017 FSB had 184 branches around the UK and these were grouped into 33 regions.<ref>{{cite web|title=FSB Annual Report 2016|url=http://www.fsb.org.uk/docs/default-source/fsb-org-uk/fsb-annual-report-and-accounts-2015-2016.pdf|website=Federation of Small Businesses}}</ref> Each branch and region has its own committee. In addition, there is a national committee which includes representatives from each regional committee.<ref>{{Cite book|title=FSB MSP|year=2016|publisher=FSB|}}</ref>
== National campaigns ==
FSB runs a number of national campaigns on behalf of its members, to highlight the needs of Small Businesses and the Self Employed. Most recently FSB ran a ‘Wellbeing’ campaign to support the health of small business owners and their staff. The campaign was backed by MIND, Public Health England, UK Active, and Seb Coe. Historically, previous campaigns have included: * Keep Trade Local: FSB Launched the Keep Trade Local campaign <ref>{{cite web|title=FSB Keep Trade Local|url=http://www.fsb.org.uk/docs/default-source/fsb-org-uk/041/assets/press-release-g8-arrives-but-keep-trade-local-140613.pdf|website=Federation of Small Businesses}}</ref> in August 2008 <ref>{{cite web|title=FSB Keep Trade Local Launch|url=https://www.fsb.org.uk/media-centre/press-releases/fsb-launches-keep-trade-local-tour-pr-2008-52|website=Federation of Small Businesses}}</ref> *Real Life Entrepreneurs: FSB launched Real Life Entrepreneurs in October 2011 <ref>{{cite web|title=FSB Real Life Entrepreneurs Launch|url=http://www.fsb.org.uk/media-centre/press-releases/essex-launch-for-national-real-life-entrepreneurs-campaign-espr-0610er|website=Federation of Small Businesses}}</ref> * #ibacksmallbusiness: FSB launched #ibacksmallbusiness campaign<ref>{{cite web|title=FSB #ibacksmallbusiness|url=https://www.fsb.org.uk/standing-up-for-you/our-campaigns/backing-small-business|website=Federation of Small Businesses}}</ref> in July 2014 <ref>{{cite tweet|user=mctague56|author=mctague56|number=486501137525530624|date=8 July 2014|title=@RobertWorcester gave FSB fascinating insight on GE 2015 predicts minority Tory Govt #ibacksmallbusiness}}</ref> The #ibacksmallbusiness campaign has been a success and is still an active hashtag.<ref>{{cite web|title=Twitter #ibacksmallbusiness|url=https://twitter.com/search?q=%23ibacksmallbusiness|website=Twitter}}</ref>
FSB also supports a number of other national campaigns on behalf of its members, to highlight the needs of Small Businesses and the Self Employed.
== Lobbying ==
FSB's past political lobbying activities have led in its own opinion to a number of benefits for small businesses,<ref>{{cite web|title=FSB Policy Issues|url=http://www.fsb.org.uk/standing-up-for-you/policy-issues|website=Federation of Small Businesses}}</ref> such as:
* Repeatedly overcoming attempts to impose unreasonable National Insurance Contributions * The introduction of enhanced capital allowances and flexible working hours * The reduction or removal of Corporation Tax for small limited companies * VAT reform in the form of a flat rate scheme for small businesses * An end to automatic fines for incorrect filing of VAT returns
== Events ==
FSB organises events aimed at supporting FSB, its members and the small business community around the United Kingdom.<ref>{{cite web|title=FSB Events|url=http://www.fsb.org.uk/events/events-introduction|website=Federation of Small Businesses}}</ref> National events are arranged by FSB's Events Team based in the Blackpool office, with the assistance of a nationwide network of staff and volunteers.
The FSB National Conference attracts more than 1,100 attendees from all over the United Kingdom<ref>{{cite web|title=FSB Conference|url=http://www.fsb.org.uk/events/past-conferences/2016-conference---glasgow|website=Federation of Small Businesses}}</ref>. Speakers have included Prime Ministers, Leader of the Opposition, Chancellor of the Exchequer and many more.
The FSB National Conference was replaced with a Business Show in 2017<ref>{{cite web|title=FSB Business Show|url=http://www.fsb.org.uk/events/2017-FSB-National-Business-Show|website=Federation of Small Businesses}}</ref>.
FSB is running a series of regional Awards to celebrate small businesses. These are open for nomination now, with 12 categories in each. The awards will take place in Spring 2018, building up to a national final in May 2018 as part of FSB’s Chairman’s Dinner.
FSB is represented at local events like Nottinghamshire County Fair, Lincoln Show, Love Business East Midlands, and others. FSB's Regions and Branches host regular meetings around the country. Generally Branch meetings are open to all members. FSB also runs business networking events around the UK.
== Membership ==
FSB is a member-led federation. Membership criteria are as follows:<ref>{{cite web|title=Membership Requirements|url=http://www.fsb.org.uk/about-us/faqs/non-member-faqs|website=Federation of Small Businesses}}</ref>
* Self-Employed or the owner, partner, or director of a business (or businesses) Based in the United Kingdom * Fewer than 250 employees. * Agree to the Members' Code of Conduct<ref>{{cite web|title=FSB Members Code of Conduct|url=https://www.fsb.org.uk/about-us/company-information/members-code-of-conduct|website=Federation of Small Businesses}}</ref> * Not barred from membership
The membership was 185,000 in 2006 and >160,000 in 2016.<ref>{{Cite book|title=FSB Annual Report 2006|year=2006|publisher=FSB|}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=FSB Annual Report 2016|url=http://www.fsb.org.uk/docs/default-source/fsb-org-uk/fsb-annual-report-and-accounts-2015-2016.pdf|website=Federation of Small Businesses}}</ref> The membership is 200,000+ if Joint, Associate, Retired, Connect and Business Creation (pre-start-up) affiliates are included.<ref>{{cite web|title=FSB Website|url=http://www.fsb.org.uk/|website=Federation of Small Businesses}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|title=FSB Entrepreneurship Manifesto|url=http://www.fsb.org.uk/LegacySitePath/campaigns/assets/entrepreneurship%20manfiest%20web.pdf|website=Federation of Small Businesses}}</ref>
== Small Business Index ==
The FSB Small Business Index measures confidence among small firms. <ref>{{cite web|title=FSB SBI|url=https://www.fsb.org.uk/standing-up-for-you/policy-issues/finance-and-the-economy/small-business-confidence-index|website=Federation of Small Businesses}}</ref> The FSB SBI has been quoted by the Bank of England,<ref>{{cite web|title=Bank of England and the FSB SBI|url=http://www.bankofengland.co.uk/publications/Documents/creditconditionsreview/2016/ccrq416.pdf|website=Bank of England}}</ref> the BBC,<ref>{{cite web|title=BBC and the FSB SBI|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-37433659|website=BBC}}</ref> Economia,<ref>{{cite web|title=economia and the FSB SBI|url=http://economia.icaew.com/en/news/april-2017/uk-businesses-report-solid-growth-in-q1-2017|website=economia}}</ref> and EADT.<ref>{{cite web|title=EADT and the FSB SBI|url=http://www.eadt.co.uk/business/single-market-access-is-priority-for-two-thirds-of-small-businesses-fsb-survey-shows-1-4940297|website=EADT}}</ref>
== Current logo == The current logo for the organisation was adopted in November 2015. The costs of this re-branding was £0.3M<ref>{{cite web|title=FSB Annual Report 2016|url=http://www.fsb.org.uk/docs/default-source/fsb-org-uk/fsb-annual-report-and-accounts-2015-2016.pdf|website=Federation of Small Businesses}}</ref> and took well over a year to complete including a complete re-branding of the FSB Website.
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== See also == *[[British Chambers of Commerce]] *[[Confederation of British Industry]] *[[TheCityUK]] *[[Institute of Directors]]
== External links == * [http://www.fsb.org.uk FSB website]

{{distinguish|Hassan Namazi}} {{Infobox Ambassador | name=Hassan Nemazee | birth_date={{birth date and age|1950|01|27}} | birth_place=[[Washington, DC]] | party=[[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] | occupation=[[Chairman]]/[[CEO]] of Nemazee Capital | alma_mater=[[Landon School]]
[[Harvard University]] | website=[http://www.nemazee.com/ Nemazee Capital] |}} '''Hassan Nemazee''' (born January 27, 1950) is a multimillionaire [[Iranian-American]] investment banker and convicted felon. ==Life== Nemazee was born in [[Washington, D.C.]] on January 27, 1950 and attended [[Landon School]], graduating in 1968. He received his Bachelor of Arts (BA) degree with Honors from [[Harvard University]] in 1972.[http://www.iranianamericanpac.org/leadership/p_nemazee.shtml Hassan Nemazee] Nemazee has not returned to Iran since the [[Iranian revolution]]. Most of his family's property was seized by the new Iranian government.{{Citation needed|date=August 2007}} On August 25, 2009 Nemazee was arrested for fraudulently applying for a loan of over $74 million from Citigroup. The maximum penalty for the offense is 30 years in prison. He was subsequently accused of fraudulently obtaining $292 million of loans from three banks and of using the proceeds to both support his lifestyle and make political contributionshttp://www.talkingpointsmemo.com/.../hassan-nemazee-indictment.php?... Nemazee is the brother of Susie Nemazee, the wife of the British Ambassador in Washington DC, Sir [[Peter Westmacott]]. Nemazee is the Chairman of Nemazee Capital.[http://www.nemazee.com NEMAZEE CAPITAL – Hassan Nemazee – 30 Years of Investment Experience] Based upon the allegations of fraud contained in Mr. Nemazee's indictment, it is difficult to determine what legitimate business, if any, was ever conducted by Nemazee Capital. ==Business interests== Nemazee Capital was established in 1987 and was purported, on its website, to have, either directly or through associated entities, invested in the following sectors: health care, media, oil and gas, insurance, investment banking, asset management, newspapers, real estate development, technology, and communications. Nemazee claims to have created Nemazee Holdings in the early 1970s and entered the financial services industry by partnering directly with AIG; at the time, according to information supplied by Nemazee, it was unique for the insurance giant to enter into such a relationship. Around this same time Nemazee claims to have created a joint venture for the establishment of a bank with Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, predecessor to [[JP Morgan & Co]]. Nemazee Capital evolved out of Nemazee Holdings and originally focused on real estate development.Please note: The majority of information contained in this entry, especially concerning Mr. Nemazee's alleged business achievements and interests cannot be verified and must be evaluated in light of his recent arrest for fraud and grand larceny. ==Political involvement== Nemazee was, prior to his arrest, also known as one of the top political bundlers in the United States. President Clinton nominated Nemazee to be Ambassador to Argentina on January 6, 1999, but the nomination was returned without action on August 5, 1999. During the [[United States presidential election, 2004]], Nemazee was a supporter of [[John Kerry]] and a major contributor to his campaign. He was the New York Finance Chair for the Kerry campaign, and later the national finance chairman of the [[Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee]].[http://marketplace.publicradio.org/shows/2006/10/30/PM200610304.html Marketplace: Hedge funds leaning blue] With Nemazee as the national finance chair, Chuck Schumer's DSCC in 2006 raised $115 million, outpacing the NRSC by substantial sums, and helping the Democratic Party take control of the Senate.http://www.changetheparty.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=53&Itemid=57 During his presidency, [[Bill Clinton]] nominated Nemazee to fill the position of U.S. Ambassador to [[Argentina]].[https://www.nytimes.com/2004/08/16/politics/campaign/16donors.html?ex=1250308800&en=0d1e94d3797ddd53&ei=5090&partner=rssuserland The New York Times > Washington > Campaign 2004 > Cash Collectors for Kerry Race Run the Gamut] Due to Congressional concerns about Nemazee's convoluted and controversial business dealings, the nomination was subsequently withdrawn{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/forbes/1999/0503/6309142a.html|title=Warning flags|author=Graham Button|date=3 May 1999|work=Forbes}} More recently, Nemazee served as Finance Chairman to Hillary Clinton's 2007-08 presidential campaign, and also donated $50,000 (the maximum amount) to Barack Obama's [[United States presidential inauguration#Presidential Inaugural Committee|Presidential Inaugural Committee]].{{cite web|url=http://www.pic2009.org/page/content/donors/|title=PicSell, promote your photos online, set up your photo gallery.|work=PicSell Australia|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081214211329/http://www.pic2009.org/page/content/donors/|archivedate=2008-12-14|df=}} In addition, Nemazee was a [[bundler (campaigning)|bundler]] for the 2009 Presidential Inaugural Committee.{{cite web|url=http://www.pic2009.org/page/content/bundlers/|title=PicSell, promote your photos online, set up your photo gallery.|work=PicSell Australia|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090220013726/http://www.pic2009.org/page/content/bundlers/|archivedate=2009-02-20|df=}} ==Arrest== Hassan Nemazee was arrested on August 25, 2009 for allegedly defrauding Citi bank by using false documents to secure a loan.https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601103&sid=aWy8uHSaXZB4 Nemazee's additional frauds exceed $100 Million, according to Federal prosecutors {{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB125192477445680911|title=Fund-Raiser Faces New Allegations|author=Chad Bray|date=3 September 2009|work=WSJ}} In July 2010 he was convicted of multiple counts of [[bank fraud]] and [[wire fraud]] and was sentenced to 12½ years in prison by U.S. District Court Judge [[Sidney H. Stein]] in the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of New York]] in Manhattan. The sentence was lighter than the 15½ to 19½ years that prosecutors had wanted. ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[https://www.nytimes.com/1960/11/13/archives/rehabilitation-in-iran-childrens-center-named-for-infant-prince-may.html "Rehabilitation in Iran"] from the New York Times *[https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0717FD3A5B167B93C2AA178BD95F408585F9 "Iranian Hospital Center Said To Rival Best In U.S."] from the New York Times *[https://www.nytimes.com/1955/05/29/archives/ustype-hospital-dedicated-by-shah.html "U.S.-Type Hospital Dedicated By Shah"] from the New York Times *[http://www.iranian.com/News/1999/June/nemazee.html "A nod for envoy to Argentina"] from Iranian.com *[http://nymag.com/nymetro/news/people/columns/intelligencer/15311/ "Blue in Your Face: Can the Democrats stay united long enough to take back the Senate? At least it's easier for them to raise money now"] from New York Online Magazine *[https://www.usatoday.com/news/politics/election2008/2008-06-24-obama-clinton-debt_N.htm?loc=interstitialskip "Obama shares fundraisers with Clinton"] from USA Today *[https://www.usatoday.com/news/politics/2008-06-22-1571558437_x.htm "Clinton, Obama Could Help Each Other Financially"] from USA Today *[http://wtop.com/?nid=213&pid=0&sid=1423778&page=1 "Clinton Asks Top Donors to Meeting With Obama"] from the AP *[http://www.backgroundnow.com/hassan-nemazee-nemazee-capital-corporations-chairman-and-ceo-arrested-this-morning/ "Hassan Nemazee, Nemazee Capital Corporation’s Chairman and CEO Arrested this Morning"] from www.BackgroundNow.com *[http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/ca765e34-75d4-11e0-82c6-00144feabdc0.html#axzz1LTKcN44s]. FT Comment. Our ambassador to Paris, Sir [[Peter Westmacott]], soon to be Ambassador in Washington, is married to Susie Nemazee, an Iranian-American. Lady Westmacott is the sister of Hassan Nemazee. *{{C-SPAN|Hassan Nemazee}} {{US Ambassadors to Argentina}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nemazee, Hassan}} [[Category:New York (state) Democrats]] [[Category:American people of Iranian descent]] [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:Iranian businesspeople]] [[Category:American fraudsters]] [[Category:American white-collar criminals]] [[Category:American political fundraisers]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:1950 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American people convicted of fraud]] [[Category:American businesspeople convicted of crimes]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Ivan Chrenko | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth based on age as of date |49|2017|03|27}}<ref name="ForbesProfile" /> | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | nationality = Slovak | residence = [[Bratislava]], Slovakia | education = | alma mater = | occupation = real estate developer | title = chairman and majority owner, [[HB Reavis]] | term = | predecessor = | successor = | known for = | boards = | salary = | networth = US $1.1 billion | spouse = | children = | parents = | relations = | website = }}
'''Ivan Chrenko''' (born 1967/68) is a Slovak [[billionaire]] businessman, the chairman and majority owner of the Slovak real estate development company [[HB Reavis]]. In March 2017, with an estimate net worth of US$1.1 billion, Chrenko became the first ever Slovak billionaire, according to ''[[Forbes]]''.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/rogeraitken/2017/03/26/a-slovak-finally-makes-it-on-forbes-billionaires-list-but-czechs-lead-way/#57e903801622 |title=A Slovak Finally Makes It On Forbes Billionaires List, But Czechs Lead Way |publisher=Forbes.com |date= |accessdate=27 March 2017}}</ref> Prior to Chrenko, [[Andrej Babiš]] became the first person of Slovak origin with a [[net worth]] above $1 billion, but he later became a citizen of the [[Czech Republic]].
Ivan Chrenko was the co-owner of [[HB Reavis]] together with Slovak multi-millionaire Viliam Pančík, and was its CEO from 1994 to October 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://hbreavis.com/en/the-people/ |title=Our People |publisher=HB Reavis |date= |accessdate=27 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Ivan Chrenko |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=233795532&privcapId=25127743&previousCapId=25127743&previousTitle=HB%20Reavis%20Management%20Spol.%20s.%20r.o |title=Ivan Chrenko: Executive Profile & Biography |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=27 March 2017}}</ref>
==Life== Ivan Chrenko was born in [[Šaľa]], [[Czechoslovakia]]. He started his first business in the mid-1990s together with his partner Viliam Pančík, specializing in audio equipment and [[electrical engineering]]. They entered the company AB Reavis in 1994, one year after its foundation. AB Reavis was specialized in real estate development in [[Bratislava]]. In 2003, AB Reavis changed its name to MPT Immo.
Chrenko experienced his first major success with the development of the Aupark shopping malls in various cities in Slovakia and Czech Republic.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://finweb.hnonline.sk/spravy-zo-sveta-financii/931196-slovensky-miliardar-chrenko-vdaci-za-majetok-realitam |title=Slovensko má prvého miliardára v rebríčku Forbesu. Ako zbohatol Ivan Chrenko? | Správy zo sveta financií | FinWeb.sk - Najlepšie správy z financií a top komentáre |publisher=Finweb.hnonline.sk |date=22 March 2017 |accessdate=1 April 2017}}</ref>
Chrenko lives in [[Bratislava]], Slovakia.<ref name="ForbesProfile">{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/ivan-chrenko/ |title=Ivan Chrenko |publisher=Forbes.com |accessdate=27 March 2017}}</ref> Chrenko does not communicate with the media and there is no published interview with Chrenko. Only two known photographs of Chrenko exist.
==See also== * [[Economy of Slovakia]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{EngvarB|date=December 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = James (Jim) Christensen | image = Jim_Christensen_Economist_Investor_and_Mathematician.jpg | caption = Jim Christensen speaking at an investment conference in 2012 | birth_place = [[Childers]], [[Queensland]] | education = [[University of Queensland]] | nationality = Australian | occupation = economist, investor, mathematician }}
'''James (Jim) Christensen''' is an economist, investor and mathematician who is currently the managing director for Global Multi-Asset at [[Queensland Investment Corporation]]. He is the former [[Chief Investment Officer]] of [[Telstra Super]] which is Australia's largest corporate superannuation fund. He has over 20 years of experience and has been widely successful in the Australian investment industry. James is heavily quoted on his economic viewpoints in various Australian and international media, and presents at numerous functions.
==Career== Jim began his career working in Queensland Treasury before moving on to the [[Queensland Investment Corporation]] (QIC). He spent over 10 years at the QIC managing some of the $54 billion the organisation was then responsible for.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.qic.com.au/who-is-qic/ |title=QIC Dynamic Investment Solutions :: Who is QIC |publisher=QIC |date=30 September 2010 |accessdate=12 December 2010}}</ref> At this company Jim was given the position of Managing Director of the Active Management Division as well as chairing the alpha investment committee.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.investordaily.com.au/archive/1346.xml |title=QIC appoints head of alpha |publisher=InvestorDaily |date=2 March 2007 |first=Charlie |last=Corbett |accessdate=12 December 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110412023330/http://investordaily.com.au/archive/1346.xml |archivedate=12 April 2011 |df= }}</ref> Ultimately, this meant Jim was responsible for determining and implementing investment strategies across all portfolios.
Jim was appointed to the role of [[Chief Investment Officer]] at [[Telstra Super]] in 2009 on 16 December, succeeding Steve Merlicek.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.investordaily.com.au/cps/rde/xchg/id/style/8251.htm |archive-url=https://archive.is/20121230103034/http://www.investordaily.com.au/cps/rde/xchg/id/style/8251.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-12-30 |title=Telstra Super appoints CIO |publisher=InvestorDaily |date=17 December 2009 |first=Julie |last=May |accessdate=12 December 2010 }}</ref> He managed over $15 billion for the company.<ref>{{cite press release |url=http://www.telstrasuper.com.au/files/a766c4ca-60ea-4d41-9ff1-9ce1009eb8dd/MR_Telstra_Super_appoints_CIO.pdf |title=New Chief Investment Officer to continue award winning performance |publisher=TelstraSuper |date=16 December 2009 |accessdate=12 December 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110107111321/http://www.telstrasuper.com.au/files/a766c4ca-60ea-4d41-9ff1-9ce1009eb8dd/MR_Telstra_Super_appoints_CIO.pdf# |archive-date=7 January 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The company is the largest corporate pension fund in Australia, with over 100,000 members.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telstrasuper.com.au/About_us/Facts_figures |title=Telstra Super Facts |publisher=Telstra Super |date=30 June 2012 |accessdate=8 February 2013}}</ref>
On 24 November 2015 Jim officially resigned from Telstra Super to return QIC, this time as Managing Director for Global Multi Asset.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afr.com/business/banking-and-finance/telstra-super-cio-jim-christensen-resigns-20151124-gl6tu2 |title=Telstra Super CIO Jim Christensen resigns |publisher=Australian Financial Review |date=24 November 2015 |accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moneymanagement.com.au/news/superannuation/telstra-super-cio-moves-back-qic-after-five-years |title=Telstra Super CIO moves back to QIC after five years |publisher=Money Management |date=25 November 2015 |accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ai-cio.com/channel/NEWSMAKERS/Australian-Corporate-CIO-Exits-for-Asset-Manager/ |title=Australian Corporate CIO Exits for Asset Manager |publisher=Chief Investment Officer |date=24 November 2015 |accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref> Jim will now be responsible for asset allocation and active management at the $74.6 Billion fund.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.qic.com.au/knowledge-centre/gma-media-release-20151124 |title=QIC Appoints Jim Christensen as Managing Director, Global Multi Asset |publisher=Queensland Investment Corporation |date=24 November 2015 |accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref> QIC is, as of Jim's appointment, the second largest investment fund in the country. In taking the position Jim has taken over from the departing CIO Adriaan Ryder who left after 7 years with the company.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ai-cio.com/channel/NEWSMAKERS/QIC-CIO-Departs-for-Middle-Eastern-Fund/ |title=QIC CIO Departs for Middle Eastern Fund |publisher=Chief Investment Officer |date=4 February 2016 |accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref>
==In the media== Over his career Jim has been featured in a number of live, televised and written pieces of media. His economic opinions have been recorded in leading magazines, journals and newspapers. These articles most commonly depict investment strategies with a particular focus on corporate asset management.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.top1000funds.com/profile/2013/08/07/telstrasuper-size-conscious-success/ |title=TelstraSuper: size-conscious success |publisher=Top 1000 Funds |date=7 August 2013 |first=David |last=Rowley |accessdate=8 September 2013}}</ref> As a speaker Jim has presented at public functions around the world including conferences with the Centre for Investor Education (CIE) and the Fund Executives Association Ltd (FEAL).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cie.com.au/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/CIO13_FinalAgenda_250213_1.pdf |title=Chief Investment Officers Symposium |publisher=Centre for Investor Education |date=27 February 2013 |accessdate=8 September 2013 }}{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.feal.asn.au/multiattachments/3161/DocumentName/FEALProgram.pdf |title=FEAL National Conference |publisher=Fund Executives Association Ltd |date=4 August 2010 |accessdate=8 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518073028/http://www.feal.asn.au/multiattachments/3161/DocumentName/FEALProgram.pdf |archivedate=18 May 2015 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cairnspost.com.au/business/port-douglas-draws-conference-with-delegates-holding-4-trillion-investment-funds/news-story/d05ce5ae7b8982239a6c18986fe65cdf |title=Port Douglas draws conference with delegates holding $4 trillion investment funds |work=The Cairns Post |date=20 October 2016 |accessdate=22 May 2017}}</ref> In addition to this he is often shown in online investor education videos.
The returns of his funds investments are also heavily highlighted and scrutinised across Australian media. For the most part funds under his control are usually industry leaders.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afr.com/personal-finance/supers-great-gains-wont-be-repeated-20140801-j6yvj |title=Super's great gains won't be repeated |publisher=Australian Financial Review |first=Sally |last=Patten |date=2 August 2014 |accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref> In 2015 Jim was listed as a nominee for the prestigious Conexus Financial Superannuation CIO of the Year award.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://investmentmagazine.com.au/2015/03/cio-of-the-year-shortlist-announced/ |title=CIO of the Year Shortlist Announced |work=Investment Magazine |date=30 March 2015 |first=Dan |last=Purves |accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref> He proceeded to win the Award, edging out his competitors at the gala event.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://investmentmagazine.com.au/2015/05/christensen-is-chief-investment-officer-of-the-year/ |title=Jim Christensen: CIO of the Year |work=Investment Magazine |first=David |last=Rowley |date=21 May 2015 |accessdate=21 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.professionalplanner.com.au/superannuation/2015/05/21/telstra-supers-jim-christensen-named-superannuation-cio-of-the-year-36901/ |title=Christensen Named CIO of the Year |publisher=Professional Planner |first=Dan |last=purves |date=21 May 2015 |accessdate=22 May 2015}}</ref> In addition to this award he went on to win CIO of the year at the Rainmaker awards in the same year.
It was reported that James was the fifth highest paid Investment Officer in the Super Industry for 2015; the highest of any corporate fund.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://investmentmagazine.com.au/2015/02/super-salary-survey-how-do-they-line-up/ |title=Super Salary Survey |date=11 February 2015 |first=David |last=Rowley |accessdate=21 May 2015}}</ref> That same year it was also shown, to some controversy, that Jim earns over $500, 000 more than the CEO of Telstra Super.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://investmentmagazine.com.au/2015/02/22-chief-investment-officers-out-earn-chief-executives/ |title=Chief Investment Officers out earn chief executives |work=Investment Magazine |date=2 February 2015 |first=Dan |last=Purves |accessdate=23 April 2015}}</ref>
==Education== James grew up in [[Childers, Queensland]] in Australia. After completing high school in [[Gin Gin, Queensland]] he went on to study at the prestigious [[University of Queensland]]. He holds a Bachelor of Science (BSc), [[Bachelor of Economics]] (BEc) and [[Master of Economics]] (MEc).
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Christensen, Jim}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Australian businesspeople]] [[Category:University of Queensland alumni]]

{{Infobox person | name = John Paul Kotter | image = John Kotter.JPG | image_size = 230px | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1947|2|25}} | birth_place = [[San Diego]], [[California]], U.S | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater = [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]
[[Harvard Business School]] | occupation = author, educator, management consultant, scholar | spouse = | website = }} '''John Paul Kotter''' is the [[Konosuke Matsushita]] Professor of Leadership, Emeritus, at the [[Harvard Business School]],{{cite web|last=Kotter |first=John P. |url=http://www.hbs.edu/faculty/Pages/profile.aspx?facId=6495&click=bestbet |title=John P. Kotter - Faculty - Harvard Business School |publisher=Hbs.edu |date= |accessdate=24 August 2014}} a New York Times best-selling author,{{cite web|title=Kotter|url=http://hbr.org/authors/kotter|publisher=www.HBR.org|accessdate=3 September 2013}} and the founder of Kotter International (a [[management consulting]] firm based in Seattle and Boston).{{cite web|title=Professor John P. Kotter|url=http://www.kotterinternational.com/aboutus/bios/john-kotter|work=www.KotterInternational.com|publisher=Kotter International|accessdate=17 September 2013}} He is a well-known [[thought leader]] in the fields of business, leadership, and change.{{cite web|url=http://www.thinkers50.com/#|title=Thinkers 50 | Scanning, ranking and sharing the best management ideas in the world|publisher=thinkers50.com|accessdate=1 January 2015}} ==Early life== Kotter graduated from the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] with a Bachelor of Science in [[electrical engineering]] in 1968 and a [[Master of Science in Management]] in 1970. Kotter then completed his [[Doctor of Business Administration]] in 1972 at [[Harvard Business School]]. Kotter is an alumnus of the [[Sigma Phi Epsilon]] fraternity. ==Career== In 1972, the same year he completed his doctorate, Kotter joined the Harvard Business School faculty. He received [[tenure]] and a full professorship in 1981. He was later named the [[Konosuke Matsushita]] Professor of Leadership. Kotter retired as a full-time faculty member from Harvard in 2001. In 2008, he co-founded Kotter International with two others, where he currently serves as Chairman.{{cite web|url=http://www.kotterinternational.com/aboutus/bios/john-kotter |title=Bios - John Kotter |publisher=Kotter International |date= |accessdate=24 August 2014}} The business consultancy firm applies Kotter's research on leadership, strategy execution, transformation, and any form of large-scale change. Since early in his career, Kotter has received numerous awards for his thought leadership in his field from ''[[Harvard Business Review]]'', ''[[Bloomberg BusinessWeek]]'',{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.businessweek.com/stories/2001-10-14/rating-the-management-gurus |title=Rating the Management Gurus |publisher=Businessweek |date=2001-10-14 |accessdate=24 August 2014}} Thinkers50, Global Gurus{{cite web|url=http://www.globalgurus.org/management/managementgurus30.php|title=Management Guru's ||publisher=globalgurus.org|accessdate=1 January 2015}} and others. ==Written Work== Kotter is the author of 20 books, 12 of which have been business bestsellers and two of which are overall New York Times bestsellers. ===''Leading Change''=== His international bestseller ''Leading Change ''(1996), "is considered by many to be the seminal work in the field of change management."{{cite web |last=Aiken |first=Carolyn |author2=Keller, Scott |title=The Irrational Side of Change Management |url=https://www.mckinsey.com/business-functions/organization/our-insights/the-irrational-side-of-change-management |date=April 2009 |work=The McKinsey Quarterly |publisher=McKinsey & Company |accessdate=18 June 2009}} William C. Finnie, Editor-in-Chief of Strategy & Leadership described it as "simply the best single work I have seen on strategy implementation".{{cite book|title=Leading Change|author=Kotter, J.P.|date=1996|publisher=Harvard Business School Press|isbn=9780875847474|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ib9Xzb5eFGQC|accessdate=1 January 2015}} The book outlines a practical 8-step process for change management : * Establishing a Sense of Urgency * Creating the Guiding Coalition * Developing a Vision and Strategy * Communicating the Change Vision * Empowering Employees for Broad-Based Action * Generating Short-Term Wins * Consolidating Gains and Producing More Change * Anchoring New Approaches in the Culture In 2011, TIME magazine listed ''Leading Change'' as one of the "Top 25 Most Influential Business Management Books" of all time.{{cite web|url=http://content.time.com/time/specials/packages/completelist/0,29569,2086680,00.html |title=Complete List - The 25 Most Influential Business Management Books - TIME |publisher=content.time.com|accessdate=1 January 2015}}{{cite news|last=Medintz|first=Scott|title=Top 25 Most Influential Business Management Books: Leading Change (1996), by John Kotter|url=http://content.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2086680_2086683_2087679,00.html|publisher=TIME.com|accessdate=17 September 2013|date=9 August 2011}} ===''Our Iceberg is Melting''=== In 2006, Kotter co-wrote ''Our Iceberg is Melting''{{cite web|url=http://us.macmillan.com/ouricebergismelting/JohnKotter |title=Our Iceberg Is Melting | John Kotter | Macmillan |publisher=us.macmillan.com|accessdate=1 January 2015}} with Holger Rathgeber where those same 8 steps were expanded into an allegory about penguins. In the book, a group of penguins whose iceberg is melting must change in order to survive while their iceberg home melts. ===''Accelerate''=== More recently, Kotter released ''Buy In'' {{cite web|url=http://www.kotterinternational.com/our-principles/buy-in |title=Buy-In - Kotter International |publisher=kotterinternational.com|accessdate=1 January 2015}} (2010), ''A Sense of Urgency''{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Sense-Urgency-John-P-Kotter/dp/1422179710 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080924174141/http://www.amazon.com/Sense-Urgency-John-P-Kotter/dp/1422179710 |archive-date=24 September 2008 |dead-url=yes |title=Amazon.com: A Sense of Urgency (9781422179710): John P. Kotter: Books |accessdate=1 January 2015 |df= }} (2008) and ''Accelerate'' (2014).{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Accelerate-Building-Strategic-Agility-Faster-Moving/dp/1625271743|title=Amazon.com: Accelerate: Building Strategic Agility for a Faster-Moving World (9781625271747): John P. Kotter: Books|publisher=amazon.com|accessdate=1 January 2015}} His educational articles in the ''[[Harvard Business Review]]'' magazine continue to be among the magazine's top sellers.{{cite web|last=Hasbe|first=Sudhir|title=25 Best-Selling Harvard Business Review articles of all time|url=http://mgmtblog.com/?p=232|work=mgmtblog.com|publisher=Management and Strategy|accessdate=17 September 2013}} His ''Harvard Business Review'' article "Accelerate!",{{cite web|url=http://hbr.org/2012/11/accelerate |title=Accelerate! - HBR |publisher=hbr.org|accessdate=1 January 2015}} where he outlines a new type of business structure, won the 2012 McKinsey Award, recognizing it as the most significant article published in the magazine that year.{{cite web|title=The 2012 McKinsey Award Winners|url=http://hbr.org/2013/04/the-2012-mckinsey-award-winners/ar/1|work=www.HBR.org|publisher=Harvard Business Review|accessdate=17 September 2013}} ==Personal life== Kotter lives in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]] and [[Ashland, New Hampshire]], with his wife, Nancy Dearman. They have two children. ==Works== * {{Cite book | publisher = John Wiley & Sons Inc | isbn = 047150540-4 | last = Kotter | first = John P. | title = Mayors In Action | location = | year = 1974 | page = }} * {{Cite book | publisher = Prentice Hall | isbn = 0138031487 | last = Kotter | first = John P. | title = Self Assessment & Career Development | location = | origyear = 1978| year = 1991 | page = }} * {{Cite book | publisher = Amacom Books | isbn = 0814455077 | last = Kotter | first = John P. | title = Power in Management | location = | year = 1979 | page = }} * {{Cite book | publisher = R. D. Irwin | isbn = 0256022267 | last = Kotter | first = John P. | title = Organization - Texts, Cases, and Readings on the Management of Organizational Design and Change | location = | year = 1979 | page = }} * {{Cite book | publisher = Free Press | isbn = 0029182301 | last = Kotter | first = John P. | title = The General Managers | location = | year = 1986 | page = }} * {{Cite book | publisher = Free Press | isbn = 1439146799 | last = Kotter | first = John P. | title = Power and Influence | location = | origyear = 1985| year = 2008 | page = }} * {{Cite book | publisher = Free Press | isbn = 0029183316 | last = Kotter | first = John P. | title = The Leadership Factor | location = | year = 1988 | page = }} * {{Cite book | publisher = Free Press | isbn = 0029184657 | last = Kotter | first = John P. | title = A Force for Change | location = | year = 1990 | page = }} * {{Cite book | publisher = Free Press | isbn = 1451655320 | last = Kotter | first = John P. | title = Corporate Culture and Performance | location = | origyear = 1992| year = 2011 | page = }} * {{Cite book | publisher = Free Press | isbn = 0029175860 | last = Kotter | first = John P. | title = The New Rules | location = | year = 1995 | page = }} * {{Cite book | publisher = Harvard Business School Press | isbn = 978-0-87584-747-4 | last = Kotter | first = John P. | title = Leading Change | location = | year = 1996 | page = }} * {{cite book |title=Matsushita Leadership: Lessons from the 20th Century's Most Remarkable Entrepreneur |last=Kotter |first=John P. |year=1997 |publisher=The Free Press |location=New York |isbn=9780684834603 |oclc=35620432 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H02ar1hD7nAC}} * {{Cite book | publisher = | isbn = | last = Kotter | first = John P. | title = John P. Kotter on What Leaders Really Do | location = | year = 1999 | page = }} * {{Cite book | publisher = | isbn = | last = Kotter | first = John P. | title = The Heart of Change | location = | year = 2002 | page = }} * {{Cite book | publisher = | isbn = | last = Kotter | first = John P. | title = Our Iceberg is Melting | location = | year = 2006 | page = }} * {{Cite book | publisher = Harvard Business School Publishing | isbn = 978-1-4221-7971-0 | last = Kotter | first = John P. | title = A Sense of Urgency | location = United States | year = 2008 | page = }} * {{Cite book | publisher = | isbn = 9781422122884 | last = Kotter | first = John P. | title = Managing Your Boss | location = | year = 2008 | page = }} * {{Cite book | publisher = | isbn = 9781422157299 | last = Kotter | first = John P. | title = Buy In | location = | year = 2010 | page = }} * {{Cite book | publisher = | isbn = 978-1625271747 | last = Kotter | first = John P. | title = Accelerate: Building Strategic Agility for a about How Organizations Rise and Fall--and Can Rise Again | location = | year = 2016 | page = 176 }} ==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{wikiquote}} * '''Joshua Bell''' (c. 1812 - 24 December 1863) was born in [[Ireland]] and immigrated to [[Canada]] with his brother and father somewhere between 1815 and 1825.
The father, Alexander, was a [[shoemaker]] and the family became successful in that business. After the father's death, the two brothers expanded the business with Joshua taking the lead role. By his death, their company, J. and T. Bell was one of the larger footwear factories in Montreal. In the 1861, it had 70 employees.<ref>[http://www.biographi.ca/009004-119.01-e.php?&id_nbr=4293 Biography at the ''Dictionary of Canadian Biography Online'']</ref>
Joshua was important to the economic history of the time in that he was a pioneer of [[mechanization]] of shoe production in Canada.
== References == {{Reflist}} "Papiers de Ludger Duvernay," ''Canadian Antiquarian and Numismatic Journal'' (Montreal), 3rd ser., VI (1909), 127–28
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bell, Joshua}} [[Category:Year of birth uncertain]] [[Category:1863 deaths]] [[Category:Canadian businesspeople]] [[Category:19th-century Canadian businesspeople]]

{{For|the politician|Julius Beer (politician)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Use British English|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Julius Beer | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date =1836 | birth_place =Frankfurt, Germany | death_date =1880 | death_place =London, England | death_cause = | burial_place = Highgate Cemetery | burial_coordinates = | residence = | nationality =British | other_names = | known_for = | education = | employer = | occupation =Businessman, banker, newspaper baron | title = | salary = | networth = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | spouse =Thyrza Beer | children =1 | parents = | relatives = [[Rachel Sassoon Beer]] <small>(daughter-in-law)</small> | box_width = }} '''Julius Beer''' (1836–1880) was a [[Germany|German]]-born [[England|English]] businessman, banker and newspaper baron. He owned ''[[The Observer]]'' from 1870 to 1880.
==Biography==
===Early life=== Julius Beer was born in 1836 in [[Frankfurt]], Germany.<ref name="egremont">[https://books.google.com/books?id=icFRTFWBbDwC&pg=PA17&dq=%22julius+beer%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=3RBcUumkBcmc0QXw9IGwDA&ved=0CFMQ6AEwBzgU#v=onepage&q=%22julius%20beer%22&f=false Max Egremont, ''Siegfried Sassoon'', Pan Macmillan, 2006, p. 17]</ref>
===Career=== He made his fortune in the [[London Stock Exchange]].<ref name="listed">[http://www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/en-478248-mausoleum-of-julius-beer-in-highgate-wes British Listed Buildings: Mausoleum of Julius Beer in Highgate (Western) Cemetery, Camden]</ref> He was a member of the [[London Banking Association]].<ref>Phillip Cottrell, ''Investment Banking in England 1856-1881'', Routledge, 2013, p. 495 [https://books.google.com/books?id=_o2ds7SWcisC&pg=PA495&dq=%22julius+beer%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Fw9cUuiBBee_0QXzhYH4Aw&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBTgK#v=onepage&q=%22julius%20beer%22&f=false]</ref>
In 1870, he purchased ''The Observer'' newspaper, which he owned until his death in 1880.<ref name="listed"/>
===Personal life=== He was married to Thyrza Beer (died 1881).<ref>[https://books.google.ca/books?id=7az8vQW_RtcC&pg=PA113&lpg=PA113&dq=Thyrza+Beer+1881&source=bl&ots=86h8uid5sd&sig=wsrtMw8xecEWiUAa3L-OyiYalYI&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjv1Yza7I7eAhXqxFQKHSwUDhgQ6AEwA3oECAUQAQ#v=onepage&q=Thyrza%20Beer%201881&f=false ''First Lady of Fleet Street'']</ref> They had a son and a daughter: *[[Frederick Arthur Beer]] (died 1903; married [[Rachel Sassoon Beer]] (1858–1927)).<ref>[https://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/Beer-Rachel-Sassoon Jewish Women's Archive]</ref> *[[Ada Sophia Beer]] (1867–1875, died aged 8 years old) The main sculpture inside the Beer Mausoleum at [[Highgate Cemetery]] represents this young girl being protected by an angel.
He died in 1880.<ref>[https://books.google.ca/books?id=spOxzrifZjcC&pg=PT153&lpg=PT153&dq=julius+beer+1880&source=bl&ots=C8JvyT16LF&sig=vrUxhnKyZ4d0AP_jlLVUOeiqMr0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjni4qn7Y7eAhWGKHwKHZJbDKAQ6AEwDnoECAkQAQ#v=onepage&q=julius%20beer%201880&f=false ''Palgrave Dictionary of Anglo-Jewish History'']</ref> His mausoleum has been [[Grade II* listed buildings in the London Borough of Camden|listed as Grade II]] since 14 May 1974.<ref name="listed"/><ref>Elisabeth Hewes, ''Betty's Travel Journals'', Paragon Publishing, 2011, p. 152 [https://books.google.com/books?id=guXzlxHKHJkC&pg=PA152&dq=%22julius+beer%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=wvpbUrvnAsWr0QX1pYFo&ved=0CF4Q6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=%22julius%20beer%22&f=false]</ref> It was designed by English architect [[John Oldrid Scott]] (1841–1913).<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=rVHqBvtuLyMC&pg=PA354&dq=%22julius+beer%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=KxJcUo0yyqLRBaqkgMgC&ved=0CEkQ6AEwBTge#v=onepage&q=%22julius%20beer%22&f=false Bridget Cherry, ''London: North'', Yale University Press, 1998, p. 354]</ref>
Buried inside Julius Beer Mausoleum in [[Highgate Cemetery]]: * Ada Sophia Beer (his daughter, d.1875) * Julius Beer (d.1880) * Thyrza Beer (his wife, d.1881) * Arnold Beer (his brother, d.1881) * Frederick (his son, d.1903)
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
