{{Infobox writer <!-- For more information see [[:Template:Infobox Writer/doc]]. --> | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_name = <!--if different--> | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1943|09|07|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Lhasa]], Tibet | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|Year|Month|Day|Year|Month|Day}} --> | death_place = | resting_place = | occupation = | language = | nationality = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | period = | genre = Poetry, non-fiction | subject = | movement = | notableworks = | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | portaldisp = }} '''Tsoltim Ngima Shakabpa''' (born 7 September 1943 in [[Lhasa]]) is a Tibetan banker, activist, writer and poet, one of the first to write in English,<ref name="Robert Barnett"/> composing poems in this language in 1967.<ref name="namsebangdzo"/> Son of the Tibetan Finance Minister [[Tsepon W. D. Shakabpa]], he left Tibet in 1950 to study at [[St. Joseph's School - North Point, Darjeeling|St. Joseph's School, Darjeeling]] in India before working for the [[Tibetan government in exile]] and settle in the United States and was naturalized American.
== Biography ==
Tsoltim Ngima Shakabpa is the youngest son of the Minister of Finance of the Tibetan Government in 1939-1950 Tsepon WD Shakabpa.<ref name="Robert Barnett">[http://www.phayul.com/news/article.aspx?id=17069&t=1&c=9 ''Voice of Tibet - a foreword by Robert Barnett''], ''[[Phayul.com]]'', 5 juillet 2007</ref> He was educated in Tibet which he left in 1950, then in India at St. Joseph's College in Darjeeling<ref>Molly Chatalic, [http://www.univ-brest.fr/digitalAssets/33/33873_cc8-9Chatalic.pdf Quand les morts parlent ... en anglais : révolte et survie dans la poésie de T.N. Shakabpa], Les Cahiers du CEIMA, Numéro 8, décembre 2012, p. 121.</ref> and the United States.
He works for the Tibetan government in exile in India as CEO of the Tibetan Industrial Rehabilitation Society founded in October 1965 by the Government of India, the Tibetan exile government and foreign aid agencies,<ref>Hubertus von Welck, [https://books.google.com/books?id=eR6qa-BQ8p0C&pg=PA139 Exile as Challenge: The Tibetan Diaspora], p. 139</ref><ref>Stephanie Römer, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Nw-hXk8rLIEC&pg=PA71 The Tibetan Government-in-Exile: Politics at Large], p. 139</ref> and rehabilitates 7000 Tibetan refugees in agribusiness camps in Himachal Pradesh.<ref name="namsebangdzo">[http://www.namsebangdzo.com/Dead_People_Talking_Collection_of_Poems_p/17192.htm Dead People Talking]</ref>
He moved to [[Cranford, New Jersey]] in the United States where he is a naturalized US citizen and lives with his American wife. There he became an international banker for the [[Republic New York|Republic National Bank of New York]] where he was assistant vice president<ref>Asia, Volumes 1 à 3, 1978, p. 40 : "The son, Tsoltim N. Shakabpa, is an assistant vice president of the Republic National Bank of New York. His memories of Tibet are faint, because when he left there in 1950, he was only 7 years old. Now a United States citizen, he lives with his American wife in Cranford, New Jersey, where their son and daughter attend public school. The young Mr. Shakabpa has become so firmly established here that he says he doubts that he would return to Tibet for more than a visit even if he could."</ref> based in Hong Kong before being appointed Senior Vice President in 1985,<ref>Asian Finance, Volume 11, Asian Finance Publications, 1985, p. 81 : "TSOLTIM N. SHAKABPA has been named senior vice president of Republic National Bank of New York. Based in the bank's regional headquarters in Hong Kong, Sha- kabpa is responsible for business development in the Asia Pacific region. He had been promoted from vice president to first vice president at the end of 1984."</ref> and then President at [[Corpus Christi, Texas]]<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20160818120536/http://www.100thousandpoetsforchange.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/10/TsoltimNShakabpaPoems.pdf Tsoltim Ngima Shakabpa], 100thousandpoetsforchange.com</ref> until he was diagnosed with a stomach cancer in 1993.<ref name="PublishAmerica">[https://books.google.com/books?id=vLHSPQAACAAJ&dq Recollections of a Tibetan], PublishAmerica, 2003</ref> He struggles and regain health through meditation and Western medicine. According to his doctors, any trace of cancer was gone.<ref>[https://sites.google.com/a/redtoenail.org/chronicles-demo/home/tsoltim-n-shakabpa Tsoltim N. Shakabpa], Chronicles of Cancera</ref> However, he was struck again by a stroke in 1999.
Despite these setbacks, he became president of the Tibetan Association of Washington and founded the festival [[Festál at Seattle Center|TibetFest]] in Seattle in the state of Washington.<ref name="namsebangdzo"/>
He continues to write poetry and in 2002 published his first book in [[Catalan language|Catalan]], ''Records d'un Tibetà''<ref>[http://bigbridge.org/BB17/bios/bios-S-to-Z.html His bio], webzine Big Bridge</ref> at Pagès Editors ([[University of Lleida]]), a Spanish publishing house, then in English in 2003.<ref name="Robert Barnett"/> In April 2002, he received the chief editor award for his achievements in poetry from the [[Poetry.com|International Library of Poetry]]. While adopting a healthy attitude towards life, he continues to fight for the independence of Tibet,<ref name="PublishAmerica" /> questioning the Tibetan autonomy requested by the Tibetan government in exile in China, which can not offer freedom as great as that enjoyed by the Tibetan refugees in the world today.<ref>[[Claude Arpi]], [https://books.google.com/books?id=vvuSXV4r2YIC&pg=PA432 Tibet, le pays sacrifié], p. 432</ref>
In 2007, he gets a prize of Saint Joseph's College in Darjeeling.<ref name="namsebangdzo"/>
In 2011, he is among the Tibetan poets who participate to [[100 Thousand Poets for Change]].<ref>Teresa Dowell, [http://www.pirenesfountain.com/archives/issue_11/100tpc/dowell.html They Don't Care... Do You?], 100 Thousand Poets for Change, 24 septembre 2011</ref>
He has a son, Wangchuk D. Shakabpa, and a daughter, Pema Yudon Shakabpa, and lives with his wife in California.<ref name="namsebangdzo"/>
== Publications == * ''Recollections of a Tibetan'', avant-propos du [[Tenzin Gyatso|Dalaï Lama]], PublishAmerica, 2003, {{ISBN|1592865984}} * ''Winds of Change: An Autobiography of a Tibetan'', Paljor Publications, 2005 * ''Odds and Ends'', 2006 * ''Voice of Tibet'', préface [[Robert Barnett (scholar)|Robert Barnett]], Paljor Publications, 2006, {{ISBN|81-86230-57-2}} * ''Dead People Talking'', Paljor Publications, 2008 * ''I Imagine'', 2009 * ''Being Tibetan'' 2010 * ''Voices of the Voiceless'', 2011
== References == <references/>
== External links == * Molly Chatalic, [http://www.univ-brest.fr/digitalAssets/33/33873_cc8-9Chatalic.pdf Quand les morts parlent ... en anglais : révolte et survie dans la poésie de T.N. Shakabpa], Les Cahiers du CEIMA, Numéro 8, décembre 2012, p. 119-139. * Tsoltim Ngima Shakabpa, [http://articles.latimes.com/1996-07-28/opinion/op-28912_1_dalai-lama Free Tibet--One Way or the Other], ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', 28 juillet 1996 * Tsoltim Ngima Shakabpa, [http://www.tibet.ca/en/library/wtn/archive/old?y=2007&m=7&p=12_6 The Case Against Autonomy for Tibet], ''WTN'', 12 juillet 2007 * Tsoltim Ngima Shakabpa, [http://tibet.ca/en/library/wtn/2611 Essay: The Role of English in Poetry by Tibetans], ''WTN'', 10 juin 2008 {{Authority control}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox Newspaper | name = WirtschaftsBlatt | logo = | image = Wirtschafts Blatt logo.svg | image_size = 220px | caption = | type = Business [[newspaper]] | format = | owners = [[Styria (company)|Styria Medien AG]] | publisher = Wirtschaftsblatt Verlag AG | editor = | chiefeditor = Wolfgang Unterhuber | assoceditor = | maneditor = | newseditor = | managingeditordesign = | campuseditor = | campuschief = | opeditor = | sportseditor = | photoeditor = | foundation = October 1995 | political = | language = German | ceased publication = 2 September 2016 | headquarters = [[Vienna]], [[Austria]] | circulation = 27,000 (2013) | sister newspapers = | ISSN = | oclc = 47862186 | website = [http://www.wirtschaftsblatt.at/ ''WirtschaftsBlatt''] }}
'''''WirtschaftsBlatt''''' (meaning ''The Business Journal'' in English) was the only daily financial newspaper published in [[Vienna]], the [[Republic of Austria]].<ref name = bpe>Business Press Europe: [http://www.business-press.org/members/austria/mag-at2.html WirtschaftsBlatt Profile] Retrieved 30 May 2012</ref> The newspaper appeared every trading day from Monday to Friday in [[German language|German]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Media Markets: Austria Country Overview|url=http://oldtelecoms.kondrashov.ru/world/austria.html|work=Russian Telecom|accessdate=1 January 2015|date=August 2004}}</ref> It was in circulation between October 1995 and September 2016.
==History and profile== First published in October 1995,<ref name=auswi>{{cite web|title=Austria 2013|url=http://www.wptdatabase.org/reports/2013/austria#wpt-report-chapter-3|work=WAN IFRA|accessdate=25 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="markel">{{cite book|editor=Mary Kelly|others=Gianpietro Mazzoleni; Denis McQuail|title=The Media in Europe: The Euromedia Handbook|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HYCVxSFNNpkC&pg=PA6|accessdate=19 April 2015|year=2004|publisher=SAGE Publications|isbn=978-0-7619-4131-6|page=6}}</ref> ''WirtschaftsBlatt'' specialized in the areas of business, economic policy, markets, stock exchanges and investment. The newspaper was published by around 50 journalists and 30 production staff. On the paper's founding, [[Styria Media Group|Styria Multimedia AG]] and the Swedish media group [[Bonnier Group|Bonnier]] each owned 50% the paper and its online portal.<ref name=markel/> In mid-2006 Styria purchased all of Bonnier's shares and became 100% owner of the newspaper.<ref>{{cite web|author=Josef Trappel|title=Media landscapes. Austria|url=http://ejc.net/media_landscapes/austria|work=European Journalism Centre|accessdate=19 April 2015}}</ref> The publisher of the paper is Wirtschaftsblatt Verlag.<ref name=auswi/><ref name=pu10/> The paper was a cooperative of the Austria Press Agency.
''WirtschaftsBlatt'' had its headquarters in Vienna.<ref name=pu10/> On 25 January 2007 the online version of the newspaper was launched. On 2 September 2016 the last issue of the paper appeared.<ref>{{cite news|title=Austria: Business daily Wirtschaftsblatt to close|url=http://www.publicitas.com/en/global/media-news-events/news-detail/?no_cache=1&newsid=130933&title=austria-business-daily-wirtschaftsblatt-to-close#.V_dx75OLT6Y|accessdate=7 October 2016|work=Publicitas|date=22 August 2016}}</ref>
== Content == * „Business and Markets“: Daily section on business and economic policy in Austria. * „Bundesländer“: Daily report on the business community in the states of Austria. * „Osteuropa“: Daily report on business and economic policy in Eastern and Central Europe. * „Finance and Securities“: Daily Stock, bond, commodity and market analyses * Special Reports: International Report; service articles on laws, regulations, and taxes; Opinion Page; and every Friday book reviews, careers and real estate. * Supplements: The Friday edition has supplements "investor", "the magazine for money" and eight times a year a glossy supplement "business daily deluxe" with topics on luxury and lifestyle.
==Circulation== ''WirtschaftsBlatt'' had a circulation of 53,000 copies in 2004.<ref>{{cite web|title=Media pluralism in the Member States of the European Union|url=http://ec.europa.eu/information_society/media_taskforce/doc/pluralism/media_pluralism_swp_en.pdf|work=Commission of the European Communities|accessdate=27 March 2015|location=Brussels|date=16 January 2007}}</ref> In 2009, according to Austrian Media Analysis (ÖWA), the newspaper was read by approximately 86,000 (on Fridays 117,000).<ref name = bpe/> The average circulation of the paper was 22,024 copies from Mondays to Fridays in 2010.<ref name=pu10>{{cite news|title=Austria: Top daily newspapers|url=http://www.publicitas.com/de/home/media-news-events/news-detail/?newsid=43588#.VNIAhGSsXRA|accessdate=4 February 2015|work=Publicitas|date=28 October 2010}}</ref> The Austrian Circulation Control (ÖAK) reported that the paper had a circulation of 34,084 in the first half of 2011.<ref>[http://www.oeak.at/content/intern/Auflagenlisten/OEAK_2011_1HJ_KORR_20120301.pdf Austrian Circulation Control 2011 report ]</ref> Its average circulation was 27,000 copies in 2013.<ref name=auswi/>
==Online service== On 25 January 2007, the newly designed online wirtschaftsblatt.at was launched. The contents of the portal was based on the WirtschaftsBlatt's line of business. According to Austrian Web Analysis (ÖWA), in 2009 www.wirtschaftsblatt.at had an annual average of 322,000 unique visitors, nearly a million visits and more than three million page views with an average duration of 5:49 minutes.<ref>Österreichische Media-Analyse: [http://www.media-analyse.at/studienPublicPresseTageszeitungTotal.do?year=2010&title=Tageszeitungen&subtitle=Total Austrian Media Market Analysis 2010]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
